content.question: Three radio stations broadcast at the following frequencies: station 1 at <math alttext="88 Megahertz" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>88</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>MHz</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, station 2 at <math alttext="500 Kilohertz" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>k</mtext><mtext>Hz</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, and station 3 at <math alttext="1400 Kilohertz" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>1400</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>k</mtext><mtext>Hz</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> . Which of the following correctly compares the stations’ broadcast wavelengths <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="lambda sub 1, equals lambda sub 2, equals lambda sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="lambda sub 1, is greater than lambda sub 2, is greater than lambda sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="lambda sub 1, is greater than lambda sub 3, is greater than lambda sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="lambda sub 2, is greater than lambda sub 3, is greater than lambda sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="lambda sub 2, is greater than lambda sub 3, is greater than lambda sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>

topic.text: 14.1: Properties of Wave Pulses and Waves

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
